comments: 2^n == 2 mod n if and only if n is a prime or a member of A001567 or of A006935. [Guy]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 22 2012; corrected by _Thomas Ordowski_, Mar 26 2016Known solutions to 2^n == 3 (mod n) are given in A050259.This sequence is conjectured to include every integer k >= 0 except k = 1. A036236 includes a proof that k = 1 is not in this sequence, and n = A036236(k) solves a(n) = k for all other 0 <= k <= 1000. - _David W. Wilson_, Oct 11 2011
references: Richard K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, F10.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Albert Frank, International Contest Of Logical Sequences, 2002 - 2003. Item 4
Albert Frank, Solutions of International Contest Of Logical Sequences, 2002 - 2003.
formula: a(2^k) = 0. - _Alonso del Arte_, Nov 10 2014a(n) == 2^(n-phi(n)) mod n, where phi(n) = A000010(n). - _Thomas Ordowski_, Mar 26 2016
example: a(7) = 2 because 2^7 = 128 = 2 mod 7.a(8) = 0 because 2^8 = 256 = 0 mod 8.a(9) = 8 because 2^9 = 512 = 8 mod 9.
maple: A015910 := n-> modp(2 &^ n,n) ; # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Feb 15 2008
prog: (Maxima) makelist(power_mod (2, n, n), n, 1, 84); /* _Bruno Berselli_, May 20 2011 */(PARI) a(n)=lift(Mod(2,n)^n) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jul 15 2011(Haskell)import Math.NumberTheory.Moduli (powerMod)a015910 n = powerMod 2 n n  -- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 17 2015
author: _Robert G. Wilson v_
